subsection.title: Univariate distributions

introduction.p: Probability distributions for discrete random variables assign probability to discrete values, but for continuous random variables, probabilities are only assigned to intervals.

statement.p: A function with values f(x), defined over the set of all real numbers is called a probability density function of the continuous random variable X if and only if P(a \le x \le b) = \int_a^b f(x)\,dx for any real a and b such that a \le b.
A probability density function is often referred to as simply a density function or a PDF

subsection.p: Do not assume that f(c) gives P(X = c). A density is not a probability, it is a probability density. Since probabilities of continuous random variables are associated with intervals, \int_c^c f(x)\,dx = 0.

statement.p: If X is a continuous random variable, the function given by \displaystyle F(x) = P(X \le x) = \int_{\infty}^x f(t) \,dt \text{ for } -\infty \lt x \lt \infty where f(t) is the value of the probability density of X at t, is called the distribution function, or the cumulative distribution (function), of X.

Given a cumulative distribution function of a continuous random variable, the construction of a probability density function, is much easier than the construction of a probability mass function, from its cumulative distribution function. For continuous random variables we will assume that the function f(x) is continuous and also differentiable every but perhaps at a finite set of values.

statement.p: If f(x) and F(x) are the values of the PDF and CDF of X at x, then P(a \lt X \lt b) = F(b) - F(a) for any real constants a \lt b and f(x) = \dfrac{dF}{dx} where the derivative exists.

Remember that if F(x) is a piecewise function, we would expect f(x) to be piecewise as well. Additionally, we need to be careful at the locations where the definition of F(x) changes, which is where f(x) is likely to change definition as well.

Consider F(x) = \begin{cases}0, \amp \quad x \lt -1\\\dfrac{x+1}{2}, \amp \quad -1 \le x \lt 1\\ 1, \amp \quad 1 \le x\end{cases}. Find the probability density function f(x).
Notice that F(x) is not differentiable at x = \pm 1 where the graph displays corners.

solution.p: For x \lt -1, f(x) = \dfrac{d}{dx}\Big(0\Big) = 0. For -1 \le x \lt 1, f(x) = \dfrac{d}{dx}\Big(\dfrac{x+1}{2}\Big) = \sfrac{1}{2}. For 1 \le x, f(x) = \dfrac{d}{dx}\Big(1\Big) = 0.
Based on the work above, f(x) = \begin{cases}0, \amp \quad x \lt -1\\\sfrac{1}{2}, \amp \quad -1 \le x \lt 1\\ 0, \amp \quad 1 \le x\end{cases}.

Since the value of the function at a single point, such as an endpoint,does not affect the value of probabilities, we will adopt the convention of specifying the non-zero part of the density on an open interval. This means we take f(-1)=f(1)=0. Thus we have, f(x) = \begin{cases}\sfrac{1}{2}, \amp \quad -1 \lt x \lt 1\\ 0, \amp \quad \text{otherwise}\end{cases}.
